REPAIRING PROMPTLY EXECUTED.

NOTICE.
Having decided to remove from Prince Albert, I hereby notify all parties in connection therewith that Mr. Stephen Brewer, my Attorney, on behalf of Mr. James Finlayson, who will be here Friday morning, February 26, 1886. The action started at the first sitting of the Saskatchewan Court, January 31st, 1886. Any payments made by me to said party will be treated as against me, and interest shall be charged on the amount remaining due at the rate of six percent per annum.

JOHN A. MACDONALD,
PRINCE ALBERT.

PRINCE ALBERT PLANTING MILLS AND SAW MILL AND DOOR FACTORY.
GORDON, DONNIGTON & MACKEY.

A. GOODFELLOW,
PRINCE ALBERT, N.W.T.

SHERIFF'S SALE OF LAND.

Under instructions from the Bank of Prince Albert, there will be a sale of land located between Lots 5 and 6, Section 20, Township 47, Range 3 West, District Municipality of Prince Albert, on the following conditions:

1. The land will be sold at public auction.
2. Any bids submitted will be considered valid.
3. All bids must be paid in full before the sale date.
4. The sale will take place at the appointed time.

For more information, contact the Sheriff's office.

NOTICE.
The City Council has issued a resolution that all residents pay their property taxes by March 31st, 1886. Any late payments will be subject to a penalty fee.

CITY OF PRINCE ALBERT.

PUBLIC NOTICE.
Take notice that an application will be made to the Parliament of Canada to incorporate the Regina River Coal Mine and Transportation Company, with power to acquire, sell, mortgage or encumber lands and minerals on the Territories of Assiniboin and Saskatchewan Province, and to mine and sell coal and laterite, to buy, hire or rent houses, buildings, wharves, piers, dams, fences and railway cars, to buy, hire, charter, operate and sell vessels, boats, barges, engines, tools and implements for coal and other fuel, and with all other powers granted by law.

For more information, contact the Clerk of the House of Commons.

TORONTO, Feb. 26.

ADAM B. MYTTON,
Secretary of the Application.

STORAGE AVIS PUBLIC.

BOOKS, STATIONERY, FANCY GOODS, ACCORDEONS, VIOLINS, VIOLIN FITTINGS,
The Latest Western Papers and Books Week.

E. J. CANN.

CHIT-CHAT LOCALS.
Gathered by our Reporters.

Notice Street at Clark's Drug Store.

OUR CHIT-CHAT VEGETABLE AMUSEMENT AND LIFT PARK.

MR. W. H. GOVERNOR is back from Ontario this week. He will be away about two weeks.

Sergeant Macdonald and Insp. Morris, N.W.M.P., returned from Bath last Monday.

Tuesday, we looked for a selection of spring and summer goods.

There will be a meeting of the district council at the Old Methodist Church on Wednesday next. Hon. Johnston, our Member of Parliament.

Sir A. Macdonald, the Prime Minister, will attend on Tuesday morning and evening at the Mission Hall.

Mr. Adams, of Prince Albert, will soon be appointed Indian Agent for this district. Mr. Adams is to be followed by Mr. Johnston.

Mr. Spooner and party leave for Carlton Tuesday next to make a correction in his horse's track, which had laid up in his eye, and expects it again.

Mr. Adams, of Prince Albert, will soon be appointed Indian Agent for this district. Mr. Adams is to be followed by Mr. Johnston.

Mr. Spooner and party leave for Carlton Tuesday next to make a correction in his horse's track, which had laid up in his eye, and hopes it will be attended by the Deputy Registrar.

NOTICE.
At the request of the Bank of Toronto, it is hereby notified that all accounts with this bank, including those of the Grand Trunk Railway, will not be paid out after midnight on December 31st, 1885.

THE PRINCE ALBERT TIMES.

PRINCE ALBERT, SASK., FRIDAY, FEBRUARY 26, 1886
NORTH WEST NOTES

EDMONTON.

From the Bulletin.

Monday and Tuesday were very cold, as signs of spring.

Rev. Pere Foy of St. Albert, has partly recovered from a second attack of rheumatic fever, but is still far from well.

The small building between the Jasper house and A. Macdonald & Co.'s store was occupied as a station by the police patrol.

Jas. Macdonald and J. Kirkness are looking for timber near the river in front of their claims a few feet above the falls.

J. Kelly has delivered a portion of the machinery required for his new mill at his claim near the White Mud. He is preparing to work the limit during the coming summer.

A desire for telegraphing has seized a portion of the population. As there is no telegraph line running, there is plenty of excellent places for timber and provisions situated.

The Hays have succeeded in attracting a large proportion of silver from quartz veins recently taken from his mining claim on the Hill Creek, up the river. He is now acquiring machinery with which to develop the claims.

The contract for the delivery of two telegraph poles on the line between Edmonton and Fort Saskatchewan was let on Wednesday to John Atwood at a cost of $1.50 per pole—a very low rate. The tenders were sent in on Tuesday forenoon, telegraphed to Edmonton, and the answer received on Wednesday afternoon.

REGINA.

From the Leader.

Wedding took place at the barracks on Wednesday evening, Corp. Aggrey and Miss Woodward were the happy couple.

Red Eagle, the wounded Indian chief captured at Fish Creek, was brought into Regina yesterday.

Messrs. Martin and Bortzberger are preparing for the brick making season of '86. Last year this firm turned out upwards of a million bricks. Should it become necessary, machines exist for the manufacture of 20,000 a day.

A nephew of Mr. L. C. McTavish, Government Agent, was accidentally drowned in a well fifteen miles north of Prince Albert on Monday night. Mr. McTavish and Mr. McTavish, nearly of Argyleshire, Scotland, was alone at the time, and when discovered was found to be in a state of shock.

On Saturday Dr. Collier held an inquest on the body of "Red Bird," killed by a bear. It appears the bear had been suffering from a case of desperation, since the death of his hunter, about a year ago, and while in its last moments it attacked the fatal weapon used. Verdict accordingly.

The directors of the Regina & Long Lake Railway and Steamboat Co., hold a meeting on Wednesday. The company is in a precarious position.

A steamboat goes on the lake in spring, and indemnities will be offered to the proprietors of Alta Vista and Battleford to adopt this as a steamer and short cut route to the C. P. R.

A Lord Mayor was elected at the meeting on Thursday. Brandy Mac, sentenced to penal servitude for life, was elected mayor over his late lordship. He denies pilfering the public money, and says he cut his heart out on a trophy big bear. Great man is a sorry sight. He is about seventy years old, mongrel, palied, and completely broken up. Humanity speaks long before him more than two years.

STONEWALL.

From the Leader.

Business is slack and all hands are apparently waiting for the usual spring thaw.

We understand that Mayor Murdoch intends calling a meeting of the town council promptly.

Messrs. Loftus and Smith are looking for premises on which to build a large store. They say their present building being too small.

That portion of township 21 of range 23 west of the third meridian, lying N.E. of Swamp Lake, has been opened for settlement.

Mr. Harvey, who was badly injured by a broken leg, a horse having fallen on him. There is a lack on this branch.

The Lt. Governor has added the name of Alexander Fogg Esq., Dunbow, north of High River, to the list of J.P.s, for the territory.

Thompson's new buildings are now completed. They are among the handsomest in town, and the offices being particularly handsome.

The following Indians—Blackfoot, the Alberta, Montana, Idaho, and Oregon bands—which we understand carry scalp with them, are selling in town at about an average of $5.

BATTLEFORD.

From the Herald.

Capt. George Young, of Winnipeg, has been appointed as a commissioner to proceed to Battleford immediately to investigate settler's cases.

The Government has decided to erect a telegraph line from Prince Albert to Edmonton.

The Aberdeen papers speak highly of the exhibit of Northwest products only on view in that city until the close of March. The Prince Albert Land Company, and, as a consequence, the display attracted more than usual attention, the number of visitors the first two days being extraordinary. The interest thus created is calculated to have much greater effect than any number of pamphlets would produce, for the proof of the quality of the soil is capable of producing such specimens of grain as we perceive as we know our prairie men can boast of, is not to be gained. This is the view taken by the managers of this interesting display, and they encourage, by their timely appearance today, are to try and secure the presence of as many as possible of the agricultural communities in the adjoining country, than whom no country can furnish a more desirable class of voters.

**SEED GRAIN.**

A good number of seed-grain for Troy this week in hand, in good condition. The commissioners let contracts for about 200 tons of freight, but have received orders from Winnipeg that the balance of the seed will be shipped by rail direct to Fort Macdonald, and the remainder of the seed will be shipped by water. The contracts will be let at Qu'Appelle. In our last issue we stated that there appeared to be some uncertainty as to the future of the business at Qu'Appelle, and we are glad to find that confidence that such is the case. In letting the contract to some firm at Qu'Appelle there was a misunderstanding as to some kind of speculation. This was due to the fact that the commissioners were not notified to come in for contracts for freight about the 20th of February. They were informed by permanent officers. When they arrived here they only received instructions concerning what a great number came from long distances and had to retrace their steps. We are glad to hear that the confusion has been cleared up, and that the business has been brought on a proper footing. A few such precautions might have prevented this misunderstanding, which we hope will not recur again.

The Canadian Pacific Railway Company is determined to give the Northwest a magnificent telegraph system. Mr. Charles R. Hooper, general manager of the Canadian Mutual Telegraph Company, who visited this district recently, Mr. Van Horne has been appointed Manager of the Canadian Pacific Railway Company, with headquarters at Montreal, and will take charge on the first of next month. The company is preparing to push forward as rapidly as possible a number of important works from Montreal to Winnipeg, which when completed will be used extensively by the farmers for carrying the wheat along store lines, and also for railway use. This is the largest and consequently the best work any telegraph line in Canada, and there are but a few miles of a similar stripe across the Continent, and the general size of the wires, according to No. 6. For the purpose of comparison it may be stated that the wires now in use by Bell Telephone Company in Winnipeg are No. 14. It is expected that the company will begin to make an effort to build business from St. Boniface and other points on its line, and when completed a few weeks later it will have direct connection with Toronto and other leading cities in Ontario. If this is the spring will have a direct connection with New York and all the other important American cities.

**FRIDAY, FEBRUARY 26, 1886.**

The contract to build the North-Western Central Railway from Edmonton to Battleford has been signed. Premier Norquay has returned from the east, and the Provincial government has signed a contract to build three hundred miles of the Hudson's Bay Railway from Nelson House to Nelson. This line will be completed in April.

The Canadian Pacific Railway Company is determined to give the Northwest a magnificent telegraph system. Mr. Charles R. Hooper, general manager of the Canadian Mutual Telegraph Company, who visited this district recently, Mr. Van Horne has been appointed Manager of the Canadian Pacific Railway Company, with headquarters at Montreal, and will take charge on the first of next month. The company is preparing to push forward as rapidly as possible a number of important works from Montreal to Winnipeg, which when completed will be used extensively by the farmers for carrying the wheat along store lines, and also for railway use. This is the largest and consequently the best work any telegraph line in Canada, and there are but a few miles of a similar stripe across the Continent, and the general size of the wires, according to No. 6. For the purpose of comparison it may be stated that the wires now in use by Bell Telephone Company in Winnipeg are No. 14. It is expected that the company will begin to make an effort to build business from St. Boniface and other points on its line, and when completed a few weeks later it will have direct connection with Toronto and other leading cities in Ontario. If this is the spring will have a direct connection with New York and all the other important American cities.

**DRESSING DOOR, $48**

Undressed do., 42

Dressed Siding, 48

Undressed do., 42

Sheeting, 30

**MANITOBA.**

PORT ARTHUR.

From the westward.

A large force of men went out to work between Winnipeg and here, and east of here, putting up telegraph wires. It is said that the work will be completed within a few weeks.

The carnival at the Northern end brought out a number of prominent ladies. The ladies wore their finery, and a young lady broke her right ankle while skating on Sunday afternoon. She was promptly carried away, and will be able to walk about in a short time.

A great number of people came out on Saturday afternoon, and the weather was very pleasant.

The City roller rink was opened on Saturday night, and the weather was very fine. The ice was smooth and hard.

**FOR THE FRONT.**

PROPOSED DEMONSTRATION IN THE BLACKFEET COUNTRY.

Prospects of a Fishing Camping Ground.

In the Blackfeet Country.

It is generally understood in military circles, that a fishing column will be sent among the Indians shortly. In fact, Major General Crook has been very active in this direction, and is said to be preparing for the advance. The plan proposes that the advance be made in small parties, and it is likely that they will be very successful, so long as the columns are only for the purpose of making a demonstration in the Blackfeet Country.

The proposed demonstration is not likely to be very successful, however, as the Indians are not likely to be disturbed by any such movement. They are well provided with food and ammunition, and are not likely to be disturbed by any such movement. They are well provided with food and ammunition, and are not likely to be disturbed by any such movement.

**ST. LARRICK.**

From the westward.

The present weather is very fine. The snow is melting, and the roads are becoming passable. The weather is very fine, and the roads are becoming passable.

**WAR DECLARED!**

W. G. RAMSAY.
